name: BBCWorld
text:
Thermal imaging cameras are popping up in many public places as lockdowns begin to ease

But can they actually help to spot coronavirus?

[Thread]

https://t.co/7nboRgZo87

name: BBCWorld
text:
Thermal cameras detect heat radiating from the body and use this to estimate your core temperature 

They are used by firefighters tackling fires, and by police to search for hidden suspects 

They are not designed to be medical devices

https://t.co/7nboRgZo87 https://t.co/1mxaZpXhjN

name: BBCWorld
text:
"These devices, in general, are less accurate than medical device thermometers like those you stick in the ear," says Professor Derek Hill

They can give a reasonable measure of skin temperature within half a degree - but that's not body temperature

https://t.co/7nboRgZo87 https://t.co/pcKSPwTe0F

name: BBCWorld
text:
A normal body temperature is 37C (98.6F), but can vary through the day and the menstrual cycle

Anything above 38C (100.4F) is considered high

Temperatures can be measured through the forehead, in the mouth, ear or armpit, and through a rectal reading

https://t.co/7nboRgZo87 https://t.co/qb8RDDffWn

name: BBCWorld
text:
Thermal imaging cameras can‚Äôt detect coronavirus, they can only measure temperature

A high temperature is just one common symptom of the virus 

Not everyone with the virus gets a temperature, and not everyone with a temperature has the virus

https://t.co/7nboRgZo87 https://t.co/64sVLV77ro

name: BBCWorld
text:
So, they could give false negatives or false positives

On its own, temperature screening "may not be very effective" the World Health Organization says

Screening has to take into account ambient temperature, and could give a false sense of security 

https://t.co/7nboRgZo87 https://t.co/T0vSjUfB52

name: BBCWorld
text:
"They are‚Ä¶ only one tool among many," says Professor James Ferryman, from the University of Reading

Read more about the effectiveness of thermal imaging cameras and other temperature-checking solutions: https://t.co/7nboRgZo87
